Award.AwardTitle: K-12 Students, Teachers, Parents, Administrators and Higher Education Faculty: Partners Helping Rural Disadvantaged Students Stay on the Pathway to a Geoscience Career.
Award.AbstractNarration: The Wright State University project "K-12 Students, Teachers, Parents, Administrators and Higher Education Faculty: Partners Helping Rural Disadvantaged Students Stay on the Pathway to a Geoscience Career" is a research-based proof of concept track 1 pilot project that tests the effectiveness of an innovative model for simultaneous K-12 teacher professional development, student learning, and workforce development. The project is building a network of science experiences designed to engage eighth and ninth grade students from the Ripley, Union, Lewis, Huntington (RULH) school district, located in rural Appalachian Ohio, and keep them on the path to a geoscience career. During each summer of the two-year project, teams of RULH students, parents, teachers, administrators and college faculty travel to the facilities of the New Jersey Sea Grant Consortium at Sandy Hook, New Jersey to study science from an Earth system perspective. Teachers have the opportunity to engage in professional development alongside their students. During each of the two academic years of the project, additional professional development enrichment is provided to RULH teachers of various disciplines by a team of university scientists and geoscience educators from the Earth System Science Education Alliance (ESSEA), a NSF funded project. RULH students engage in problem-based science learning in the eighth grade and have the opportunity to take a course in Earth system science in the ninth grade that will earn them both high school and college science credits. Students also engage in community outreach by hosting community science events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project titled K-12 Students, Teachers, Parents, Administrators and Higher Education Faculty: Partners Helping Rural Disadvantaged Students Stay on the Pathway to a Geoscience Career is a research-based proof of concept track 1 pilot project that tested the effectiveness of an innovative model for simultaneous K-12 teacher professional development, student learning and geoscience workforce development. The project developed a network of science experiences designed to keep eighth and ninth grade students from the Ripley, Union, Lewis, Huntington (RULH) Ohio school district on the path to a geoscience career. The project used an Earth system science approach with student activities aligned with workforce needs. This includes the use of data and the scientific method, problem based learning and critical thinking skills. During the two-year performance period and one year no-cost extension of the project the following outcomes were met as described below:

  • Increasing RULH student interest in Earth system science and in careers in geoscience through age appropriate inquiry learning experiences in the field, laboratory and classroom.

 

This outcome was met by bringing seventh and eighth grade students, along with parents, teachers and administrators to the facilities of the New Jersey Sea Grant Consortium at Sandy Hook, New Jersey for a week long inquiry based exploration of the marine environment each summer. Visits to a NOAA research laboratory enabled participants to  better understand what researchers did and what academic preparation would be necessary to prepare for a career in the geosciences. This summer experience was followed in the academic year by specific Earth system problem based learning activities and a dual high school-college credit Physical science/Earth system science course. This led to increased Earth system science literacy for all junior high and high school students in the partnership RULH school district and strengthened geoscience education for all students through research based teacher professional development.

 

  • Building RULH teacher Earth system science content and pedagogical knowledge by providing research based professional development from a team of university scientists, geoscience educators and the Earth System Science Education Alliance, a NSF funded project.

 

This outcome was met by providing targeted professional development to teachers throughout the academic year and during the summer field and laboratory experiences at the New Jersey Sea Grant Consortium. Working alongside their students, teachers received the unique opportunity of interacting with their students during their own professional development during the summer and in teams of colleagues during the academic year.

 

  • Improving the Earth system science content knowledge and literacy of RULH students.

 

This outcome was met when teachers who had received professional development and then constructed research based inquiry classroom activities for all their students, not just those students who travelled to Sandy Hook. Collaboration with other teacher colleagues in science, mathematics civics and other curriculum areas further synergized the impact of the teacher professional development on all junior high and high school students in the RULH district.

 

  • Supporting the development of a web of community stakeholders to support students in remaining on the pathway to Earth system science literacy and possible geoscience careers.
